That is because, let's see, through all this anecdote of her illiteracy and all her own spelling that is not fixed and that we do not dare to read as it is, because it would make her too much of a parody, but no, I am as afraid of making a parody of María San José as I am of making a fool of us, and I think we were going to do it. But it is important to say it and to point it out, because I believe that this spelling of hers is not so much because she has just learned to read, but because she has just learned to read and write and I have this spelling of hers, so ignorant, because it seems that she wants to place herself in that idea of the Holy Ignorance, which was like a common place of the time, a celebration of feminine sanctity achieved through ignorance against which Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz had rebelled so much during the same times. So she seems to play a little bit with that and that is why she uses the spelling as she pleases and how it suits her. But in spite of that, that patina of clumsiness, of ignorance, all that talent that she really has, she can't stop it, that is, she can't hide it anymore. And where you can see a lot of it. And also when she has to describe, for example, her torments, she has an overwhelming descriptive talent, her excellent prose is the moment in which it appears the most. And again we are going to give her the floor, because you have to see how she describes her torments with the cilices.

utterances.speaker: B
utterances.text: Claro, vamos a cerrar este episodio cediendo la palabra para que veáis cómo describe eso. El uso de cilicios. El orden que tuve en ponerme cilicios fue, como diré aquí, los dos que mi padre dejó en su muerte. Estos me sirvieron para la cintura, para los brazos y muslos no los haya a propósito. Más como mi hermana Leonor, que era mayor que yo, estaba ya enseñándome para entrar a ser religiosa en el convento de carmelitas de nuestra madre Santa Teresa de Jesús. Segunda mención. Me enseñó a tejerlos y hacerlos de cerdas. Y entre yo y ella los hacíamos. O sea, imagínate a la hermana y ella haciendo los cilicios en la hacienda. Sólo en esto me acompañó, porque no la llevaba Dios por camino tan áspero y estrecho como a mí. Estos me los ponía en los brazos y en los muslos por la mañana. Así que me levantaba tan apretados que se me ponían las manos moreteadas y casi negras. Me las andaba escondiendo porque no me las vieran. En siendo ya el mediodía, que era ya la hora de comer, me los quitaba. El que me puse en la cintura era tan grande que me sobraba un pedazo. Carmen, es que es durísimo este. Desde el primer día que me lo puse me lo volví a quitar. Lo que hacía era apretando más y más las cintas con que estaba atado y conforme fue andando el tiempo, se iba enterrando en las carnes. Eran tantas las sabandijas que llaman piojos que crió el cilicio de cerdas que comúnmente crían los que visten lana y de que no escapan los de lino y Holanda. Fue mucho lo que padecí y grande la molestia con esta mala gente. Los piojos son la mala gente. Los sentía andar como hormigas en las llagas que se me habían hecho en la cintura, que casi me andaban comiendo sobre los huesos de las costillas. Los charcos de podre amanecían en el suelo donde dormía lo de lo que emanaban las llagas. Nada de esto me parecía mucho antes. Deseaba hacer más rigores y más penitencias.
utterances.text_en: Of course, let's close this episode by yielding the floor so you can see how he describes that. The wearing of cilices. The order I had in putting on cilices was, as I will say here, the two that my father left at his death. These served me for the waist, for the arms and thighs I did not have them on purpose. But since my sister Leonor, who was older than me, was already teaching me to become a nun in the Carmelite convent of our mother Saint Teresa of Jesus. Second mention. She taught me how to weave them and make them out of bristles. And between me and her we made them. That is to say, imagine the sister and she making the cilices in the hacienda. Only in this she accompanied me, because God did not take her on such a rough and narrow path as he took me. She used to put them on my arms and thighs in the morning. So I would get up so tight that my hands would get bruised and almost black. I used to hide them so they wouldn't be seen. By noon, when it was already lunchtime, I would take them off. The one I wore around my waist was so big that I had a piece left over. Carmen, this one is really hard. From the first day I put it on I took it off again. What I did was to tighten more and more the ribbons with which it was tied and as time went by, it was burying itself in my flesh. There were so many vermin, which they call lice, that the sow's hair sackcloth, which is common among those who wear wool and from which those who wear linen and Holland do not escape, bred. I suffered a lot and was very annoyed with these bad people. The lice are the bad people. I felt them crawling like ants in the sores that I had made on my waist, and they were almost eating on the bones of my ribs. Puddles of rot would dawn on the floor where I slept from what the sores emanated. None of this seemed much to me before. I wished to do more rigors and more penances.

utterances.speaker: A
utterances.text: Hemos dicho que las hijas de Felipe no tenemos imaginación numérica ni visual, pero tenemos mucha imaginación sensorial. Sabemos que vosotras también habéis sentido estos silicios en vosotras. Ojalá tener la mitad del talento narrativo y descriptivo de María San José para hacer las tesis un poquito más apasionantes.
utterances.text_en: We have said that Philip's daughters do not have numerical or visual imagination, but we have a lot of sensory imagination. We know that you have also felt these silences in yourselves. We wish we had half the narrative and descriptive talent of María San José to make our theses a little more exciting.

utterances.speaker: B
utterances.text: A lo que nos vamos ahora. Mañana. Ya mañana. Bueno, hasta dentro de dos semanas.
utterances.text_en: To what we are going now. Tomorrow. Tomorrow already. Well, see you in two weeks.
